Zero-knowledge proofs are no longer just technical tools; they‚Äôre now valuable and tradeable assets.
 
Succinct (@SuccinctLabs) is building the future of zero-knowledge computing. If Bitcoin has miners, Ethereum has Stakers, Succinct has ‚ÄúPROVERS‚Äù

Think of it as a global compute network where anyone can request and access cryptographic proofs on demand.
 
üîé  Key Highlights You Need To Know:

‚úÖ Succinct is Making Zero-Knowledge (ZK) Simple for Everyone:

Old ZK tech was hard and highly specialized‚Äîlike coding in assembly language. Also, only cryptography PhDs could use it effectively. With SP1, Succinct makes ZK easy‚Äîjust write normal code.

‚úÖ  How Does SP1 Work?

SP1 is a next-gen zkVM that‚Äôs 10x faster than other solutions. It can prove the correct execution of any software. This means:

üëâ Game outcomes can be proven fair
üëâ DeFi transactions can be verified
üëâ AI outputs can be audited for honesty
 
‚úÖ $PROVE token for The Prover Network

üî∏ Developers pay for proofs using $PROVE tokens

üî∏ GPU operators compete in global ‚Äúproof contests‚Äù to win the task which drives:

üëâ  Competition ‚Üí Lower proof costs  
üëâ Infrastructure growth ‚Üí More GPUs worldwide
üëâ  It mirrors how Bitcoin mining built a global hardware network‚Äîbut for ZK computing
 
Why It Matters?

üî∏ Succinct is turning ZK proofs into mainstream infrastructure

üî∏ Makes trustless, verifiable computing accessible to all developers‚Äînot just cryptography experts

üî∏ Opens the door for scalable, secure, and decentralized apps across industries

Disclaimer - we have invested in Succinct so please don‚Äôt forget to do your research.

3/3

I cannot say for sure what the problem is, but I think it has to do with the falling response rates, as detailed in the repost.
----
To be clear, I share the alarm of many that Trump is accusing the BLS of being political and firing its commissioner. As is often the case, Trump correctly identifies a problem, but may be in the process of making it worse (political).

I would further criticize the BLS by saying they brought this on themselves by continuing to push an ever-worsening report, and arguing it's the best anyone can do, and if anybody's got a better idea, they then whine that they need tons of money to implement it and continue with their flawed process.

nitter.net/biancoresearch/status/‚Ä¶

2/3

Also in 2022, the BLS has consistently OVERestimated the jobs (meaning they get revised lower). Over the past 50 years, they have UNDERestimated jobs (meaning the estimate was revised upward). 

For decades, the BLS had been undercounting the working-age population, which is why the cumulative revisions increased. However, their estimation is now off in the opposite direction. They start with too many jobs and revise lower.

Given the consternation in markets over the last few years (not just Trump on Friday) about the jobs report getting revised lower, this is a bigger problem than starting too low and revising upward.

1/3
Something happened in the last few years that has led to larger, more volatile revisions.

My version of the repost chart, with a similar trendline.  It improved with the use of better sampling techniques, as labeled.

But in 2022, the revisions started to increase again.

@NickTimiraos @chamath @BobEUnlimited @NateSilver538 @ernietedeschi

Many do, ADP, UI Claims, and Employ surveys by ISM, NFIB, the Conf. Board, UMich, and regional FRBs. 

Some of the list above might be better than the BLS.

Accuracy does not make money. It's replicating the flawed/incorrect inputs (the BLS!) that the Fed uses to move rates.

Reverse engineering broken models is hard.
Finance as entertainment: As US option volumes reach records, Tom Sosnoff's tastytrade is selling complex strategies to retail traders through live shows and videos bloomberg.com/news/features/‚Ä¶

In recent years, all survey response rates have collapsed (chart). This is true for a political survey, a business customer satisfaction survey, or a government economic survey, which have seen respondents refuse or become uninterested in participating. This leads to ever larger error rates.

The trend in the chart is not reversing, so expect it to get worse.

(My take: technology has made surveys easy to conduct, and way too many exist. So they lose their appeal. Not helping is the perception that political polls are biased and highly inaccurate, which has "poisoned the well" for all surveys. Furthermore, social media now provides people with an outlet to express their opinions. Filling out surveys, no matter their intention, has lost its appeal.) 
---
See how the University of Michigan Consumer Confidence Survey has been poisoned by partisanship.  Three years ago, the Federal Reserve proclaimed this one of its most important indicators.

The era of surveys is over. Unfortunately, surveys are the backbone of economic data. What is now required is to measure actual output, not samplings or opinions about it.

In the case of the jobs market, the solution can be to connect with the IRS databases and obtain real-time withholding data for every job in the country.

BLS statisticians and IRS employees will likely agree and then drone on about the cost. 

The cost can be free.  @elonmusk  tried to do it for free, and DC rebuffed him. If you don't like him, call Alex Karp @PalantirTech, CEO of Palantir, I'll bet you can talk him into doing it for free. Others might say the same.

Government statisticians seem to have as their goal flawless execution of a flawed process. This has to change.

@chamath @NickTimiraos  @BobEUnlimited

Moreover, a third were extremely optimistic that their business would perform better in the coming three months, and nearly a third expect to add more employees by then.

Let me get this straight... It's 'criminal' to set my own price for MY OWN product in a FREE market? And you're supposedly a stock trader benefiting from capitalism? Seriously? üòÇ I suggest a quick refresher on how free markets actually work‚Äîmaybe start with the definition of irony." Lol! ü§£
Imagine if your ridiculous standard was imposed on the companies you trade every day. Apple wouldn't exist. Tesla would be bankrupt. Hermes bags and Rolex watches selling for $50,000, despite costing $1,500 to produce (our profit margins are FAR less), would be 'criminal enterprises. Seriously? Your logic isn't so flawed‚Äîit's laughable. Welcome to capitalism, my friend; this is how value works. Time to wake up."
How about the MILLIONS of my own dollars I risked developing proprietary software? How about the MILLIONS I spend every year building and maintaining a world-class support team (and the MILLIONS I pay in payroll every year) dedicated to our members' success? Am I supposed to provide that investment and expertise for charity or just for kicks? You're absolutely delusional. ü§°
Let's get real: No one is forcing you to buy. Our platform and training programs are among the most successful in the trading industry‚Äîtransforming countless lives and empowering traders around the globe. MANY of the world's top-performing traders who are OUR clients would emphatically disagree with your uninformed take.
The FACTS overwhelmingly confirm our service is one of the strongest value propositions in the business. Your comments have ZERO credibility since you‚Äôre criticizing a product you've never even tried. For the record, the annual plan is just $499 per month‚Äîa modest price for elite knowledge and tools that can pay you for a lifetime.
Educate yourself before you embarrass yourself further. Start with a minervini.com membership.
On a final note: thank you for your service as a veteran.‚ù§Ô∏è
A Ferrari is not a commodity, and neither is the best education, tools, and training. Be smart from the start. minervini.com
